Preview text
EVOLUTIONARY COMPUTING is the field of research that draws ideas from evolutionary biology in order
to develop search and optimization techniques for solving complex problems.
Darwin proposed that a population of individuals capable of reproducing and subjected to (genetic)
variation followed by selection result in new populations of individuals increasingly more fit to their
environment.
There are several types of EAs, among which the most classical ones are genetic algorithms, evolution
strategies, evolutionary programming, and genetic programming.
PROBLEM SOLVING AS A SEARCH TASK
Under the evolutionary perspective to be studied in this chapter, a problem may be understood as a
collection of information from which something (e., knowledge) will be extracted or inferred.
the function itself, f(x) = x 3 + x + 3 and we have to minimize the value of f(x).
The process of problem solving corresponds to taking actions (steps), or sequences of actions (steps),
that either lead to a desired performance or improve the relative performance of individuals. This
process of looking for a desired performance or improved performances is called search.
Three main concepts are then involved in problem solving
    1. Choice of a representation: encoding of alternative candidate solutions (individuals) for
       manipulation like in above equation we can have different value of x in the defined boundaries.
    2. Specification of the objective: This is a mathematical statement of the task to be achieved like
       for the above expression we can write it as min(f(x)).
    3. Definition of an evaluation function: it is the function that is used to evaluate the quality of the
       candidate solution.
Search problem can be of both maximization or minimization like min(f(x) = max -f(x).
The point that satisfies the objective function is called global solution. However, it is not possible to find
the global solution in all the cases so we find the best solution.
Search techniques does two things exploiting the best solutions found so far and at the same time
exploring the search space.
The figure describes the global minima that is actual the correct solution. However, while exploring for
the best solution, we may end up with minimum solution generally termed as local minima.
Hill Climbing
Hill climbing is a local search method that uses an iterative improvement strategy.
At each iteration, a new point x&#039; is selected by performing a small displacement or perturbation in the
current point x
x&#039; = x + ∆x
Termination occurs when one of the following stopping criteria is met:

No further improvement can be achieved. • A fixed number of iterations have been performed. • A
goal point is attained.
Iterative hill climbing algorithms is given below:
Issues with hill climbing algorithm or drawback


The Procedure for simulated annealing is described below:
Based on the comparison is
Application can be the minimization of the functions like g(x)= 2x 2 sin(5x)
Representation. The most straightforward representation, in this case, is to use the real value of variable
x to represent the candidate solutions to the problem
Objective. The objective for this problem is to find the maximal value of the function g(x); that is, min
g(x)
Evaluation. The evaluation function used to determine the relative quality of candidate solutions is
obtained by simply evaluating the function g(x) for the values of x
Any evolutionary system presents a number of features:
    1. Population(s): in all evolutionary systems there are populations, or groups, of entities, generally
       termed individuals.
    2. Reproduction: in order for evolution to occur, the individuals of the population(s) must
       reproduce either sexually or asexually.
    3. Variation: there is variation in one or more characteristics of the individuals of the population(s).
    4. Hereditary similarity: parent and offspring individuals present similar characteristics. Over the
       course of generations, there may be changes in the proportions of individuals with different
       characteristics within a population; a process called descent with modification.
    5. Sorting of variations: among the sorting processes, it can be emphasized chance (random
       variation in the survival or reproduction of different variants), and natural selection (consistent,
       non-random differences among variants in their rates of survival and reproduction).
Darwin describes some basic rules that promote improvements in organisms: reproduce, change and
compete for survival.
Natural selection was the term used by Darwin to explain how new characters arising from variations
are preserved.
In summary, according to Darwin’s theory, evolution is a result of a population of individuals that suffer:

Reproduction with inheritance. • Variation. • Natural selection.
Standard Evolutionary Algorithm A standard evolutionary algorithm can be proposed as follows:

A population of individuals that reproduce with inheritance. Each individual represents or encodes a
point in a search space of potential solutions to a problem. These individuals are allowed to reproduce
(sexually or asexually), generating offspring that inherit some features (traits) from their parents. These
inherited traits cause the offspring to present resemblance with their progenitors.
Genetic variation. Offspring are prone to genetic variation through mutation, which alters their
genetic makeup. Mutation allows the appearance of new traits in the offspring and, thus, the
exploration of new regions of the search space.

Natural selection. The evaluation of individuals in their environment results in a measure of
adaptability, quality, or fitness value to be assigned to them. A comparison of individual finesses will
lead to a competition for survival and reproduction in the environment, and there will be a selective
advantage for those individuals of higher fitness.





Crossover
Two strings x = x 1 x 2 ... xl and y = y 1 y2 ... yl are selected from the current population P.
A number r indicating the crossover point is randomly selected from {1, 2, ... , l−1}.
Two new strings are formed from x and y by exchanging the set of attributes to the right of position r,
yielding x’ = x1 ... xi yi+1... yl and y’ = y1 ... yi xi+1 ... xl.
Mutation
mutation is a process wherein one allele of a gene is randomly replaced by (or modified to) another to
yield a new chromosome (structure).
The numbers r,...,u indicating the positions to undergo mutation are determined by a random process
where each position has a small probability pm of undergoing mutation, independently of the other
positions.
A new string x’ = x1...xr...xu.. is generated where xr.. are drawn at random from the set of alleles for
each gene. In the case of bitstrings, if a position has an allele ‘0’, then it becomes ‘1’, else if it is originally
‘1’, then it becomes ‘0’
In the standard GA, selection - select - is performed via Roulette Wheel, reproduction - reproduce - is
performed by crossing-over pairs of the selected individuals, and genetic variation - variate - is
performed via mutation. Fitness evaluation - eval - depends on the problem under study
GA has the following main features: • Binary representation of the data structures. • Fixed population
size. • Single-point crossover. • Point mutation. • Roulette Wheel selection.
A Step by Step Example: Pattern Recognition (Learning)
Let us assume 3X3 matrix in which black is represented by 0 and gray can be represented by one.
Initially a random population of 8 individual is generated as
Fitness Evaluation: for fitness function hamming distance between individual and pattern to be learned.
h = [6,7,9,5,5,4,6,7] now as distance is dissimilarity so we subtract it with maximum length to get
similarity.
f = [f1, ... , f8] = [6,5,3,7,7,8,6,5].
Now apply roulette wheel, divide each fitness by total fitness and multiply by 360.
Then we can have crossover and mutation operator until the optimal solution is not found.
In GP chromosome can be of variable length like for the above trees it can -41 and –(*24)
GP requires two S-expressions as inputs. However, recombination cannot be random in this case, for it
has to respect the syntax of the programs. This means that different crossover points may be chosen for
each of the parent S-expressions. The crossover point isolates a sub-tree from each parent S-expression
that will be exchanged to produce the offspring.
Mutation in GP may be useful but is not always used. Mutation may be important for the maintenance
and introduction of diversity and also to maintain a dynamic variability of the programs being evolved.
Terms used in Biology and there counter parts in Evolutionary algorithm.

<div class="_3556d27af1db" id="document-preview-text"><p>EVOLUTIONARY COMPUTING is the field of research that draws ideas from evolutionary biology in order
to develop search and optimization techniques for solving complex problems.
Darwin proposed that a population of individuals capable of reproducing and subjected to (genetic)
variation followed by selection result in new populations of individuals increasingly more fit to their
environment.
There are several types of EAs, among which the most classical ones are genetic algorithms, evolution
strategies, evolutionary programming, and genetic programming.
PROBLEM SOLVING AS A SEARCH TASK
Under the evolutionary perspective to be studied in this chapter, a problem may be understood as a
collection of information from which something (e., knowledge) will be extracted or inferred.

The process of problem solving corresponds to taking actions (steps), or sequences of actions (steps),
that either lead to a desired performance or improve the relative performance of individuals. This
process of looking for a desired performance or improved performances is called search.
Three main concepts are then involved in problem solving

    3. Definition of an evaluation function: it is the function that is used to evaluate the quality of the
       candidate solution.
Search problem can be of both maximization or minimization like min(f(x) = max -f(x).
The point that satisfies the objective function is called global solution. However, it is not possible to find
the global solution in all the cases so we find the best solution.
Search techniques does two things exploiting the best solutions found so far and at the same time
exploring the search space.</p>

the best solution, we may end up with minimum solution generally termed as local minima.

Any evolutionary system presents a number of features:
    1. Population(s): in all evolutionary systems there are populations, or groups, of entities, generally
       termed individuals.
    2. Reproduction: in order for evolution to occur, the individuals of the population(s) must
       reproduce either sexually or asexually.
    3. Variation: there is variation in one or more characteristics of the individuals of the population(s).
    4. Hereditary similarity: parent and offspring individuals present similar characteristics. Over the
       course of generations, there may be changes in the proportions of individuals with different
       characteristics within a population; a process called descent with modification.
    5. Sorting of variations: among the sorting processes, it can be emphasized chance (random
       variation in the survival or reproduction of different variants), and natural selection (consistent,
       non-random differences among variants in their rates of survival and reproduction).
Darwin describes some basic rules that promote improvements in organisms: reproduce, change and
compete for survival.
Natural selection was the term used by Darwin to explain how new characters arising from variations
are preserved.
In summary, according to Darwin’s theory, evolution is a result of a population of individuals that suffer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Reproduction with inheritance. • Variation. • Natural selection.
Standard Evolutionary Algorithm A standard evolutionary algorithm can be proposed as follows:</li>

<li>A population of individuals that reproduce with inheritance. Each individual represents or encodes a
point in a search space of potential solutions to a problem. These individuals are allowed to reproduce
(sexually or asexually), generating offspring that inherit some features (traits) from their parents. These
inherited traits cause the offspring to present resemblance with their progenitors.<ul>
<li>Genetic variation. Offspring are prone to genetic variation through mutation, which alters their
genetic makeup. Mutation allows the appearance of new traits in the offspring and, thus, the
exploration of new regions of the search space.</li>

<li>Natural selection. The evaluation of individuals in their environment results in a measure of
adaptability, quality, or fitness value to be assigned to them. A comparison of individual finesses will
lead to a competition for survival and reproduction in the environment, and there will be a selective
advantage for those individuals of higher fitness.</li>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
<p>Crossover
Two strings x = x 1 x 2 ... xl and y = y 1 y2 ... yl are selected from the current population P.
A number r indicating the crossover point is randomly selected from {1, 2, ... , l−1}.
Two new strings are formed from x and y by exchanging the set of attributes to the right of position r,
yielding x’ = x1 ... xi yi+1... yl and y’ = y1 ... yi xi+1 ... xl.
Mutation
mutation is a process wherein one allele of a gene is randomly replaced by (or modified to) another to
yield a new chromosome (structure).
The numbers r,...,u indicating the positions to undergo mutation are determined by a random process
where each position has a small probability pm of undergoing mutation, independently of the other
positions.
A new string x’ = x1...xr...xu.. is generated where xr.. are drawn at random from the set of alleles for
each gene. In the case of bitstrings, if a position has an allele ‘0’, then it becomes ‘1’, else if it is originally
‘1’, then it becomes ‘0’
In the standard GA, selection - select - is performed via Roulette Wheel, reproduction - reproduce - is
performed by crossing-over pairs of the selected individuals, and genetic variation - variate - is
performed via mutation. Fitness evaluation - eval - depends on the problem under study
GA has the following main features: • Binary representation of the data structures. • Fixed population
size. • Single-point crossover. • Point mutation. • Roulette Wheel selection.

<div class="_98347cadbf73"><div class="p2hv" id="page-container-wrapper"><div id="page-container"><div id="pf1" data-page-no="1" style="border-radius:20px;margin-bottom:34px;content-visibility:auto;opacity:1;transition:opacity 0.3s ease-in-out" class="pf w0 h0"><div class="page-content" style="display:block"><div class="pc pc1 w0 h0" style="display:block"><img class="bi x0 y0 w1 h1" alt="" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://d3tvd1u91rr79.cloudfront.net/fc05a2cde29263b1c3cb5f16b925f869/html/bg1.png?Policy=eyJTdGF0ZW1lbnQiOlt7IlJlc291cmNlIjoiaHR0cHM6XC9cL2QzdHZkMXU5MXJyNzkuY2xvdWRmcm9udC5uZXRcL2ZjMDVhMmNkZTI5MjYzYjFjM2NiNWYxNmI5MjVmODY5XC9odG1sXC8qIiwiQ29uZGl0aW9uIjp7IkRhdGVMZXNzVGhhbiI6eyJBV1M6RXBvY2hUaW1lIjoxNzA1MTg5MjAwfX19XX0_&Signature=hQJFHw6KxhqsRxngXPdBylNaIi9TECVgQoNdVEAaakfQgrj1aK9mkyakna1LwnEZAQJ-Nw6XGiW30l2Q6zXa35Otid5Ac-2kQC7jQFstZv~Tqxko-0E2YQYw0qfh-OKZPrGE8PfUlSzEFK6M8ueI9a2R-0dhsQkZPdzyD~jBwkCs0~tKSmrEB70h-YSEWeMMpysO2F0vDtmhapNqnTT8mphG0Wm5eBANrKuu6NKzb4gKmR6OVV0mHxs6yk88~WY5SFEjA31omiuC5iKHZPYFfHgG09Zi1MDili~weNgFu8Dd40rKZA5PD8Yi6-uajogyY4527bNt~T2l2sayppGFhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAJ535ZH3ZAIIOADHQ" fetchpriority="high" decoding="auto"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">EVOLUTIONARY COMPUTING <span class="ff2">is the field of research that draws ideas from evolutionary biology in order </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y2 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">to develop search and optimization techniques for solving complex problems.</div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y3 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">Darwin proposed that a population of individuals capable of reproducing and subjected to (genetic) </div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y4 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">variation followed by selection result in new populations of individuals increasingly more fit to their </div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y5 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1">environment.</div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y6 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">There are several types of EAs, among which the most classical ones are genetic algorithms, evolution </div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y7 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">strategies, evolutionary programming, and genetic programming.</div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h3 y8 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">PROBLEM SOLVING AS A SEARCH TASK</div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y9 ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">Under <span class="_ _0"> </span>the <span class="_ _0"> </span>evolutionary <span class="_ _0"> </span>perspective <span class="_ _0"> </span>to <span class="_ _0"> </span>be <span class="_ _0"> </span>studied <span class="_ _0"> </span>in <span class="_ _0"> </span>this <span class="_ _0"> </span>chapter, <span class="_ _0"> </span>a <span class="_ _0"> </span>problem <span class="_ _0"> </span>may <span class="_ _0"> </span>be <span class="_ _0"> </span>understood <span class="_ _0"> </span>as <span class="_ _0"> </span>a </div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 ya ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">collection of information from which something (e.g., knowledge) will be extracted or inferred.</div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 yb ff2 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls1 ws0">the function itself, f(x) = x<span class="fs1 ls0 v1">3</span> + x + 3 and we have to minimize the value of f(x).</div>

<section class="_b75447f6f2d3"><h3 class="_550fbc3b0f2a">Preview text</h3>
<div class="_3556d27af1db" id="document-preview-text"><p>EVOLUTIONARY COMPUTING is the field of research that draws ideas from evolutionary biology in order
to develop search and optimization techniques for solving complex problems.
Darwin proposed that a population of individuals capable of reproducing and subjected to (genetic)
variation followed by selection result in new populations of individuals increasingly more fit to their
environment.
There are several types of EAs, among which the most classical ones are genetic algorithms, evolution
strategies, evolutionary programming, and genetic programming.
PROBLEM SOLVING AS A SEARCH TASK
Under the evolutionary perspective to be studied in this chapter, a problem may be understood as a
collection of information from which something (e., knowledge) will be extracted or inferred.

The process of problem solving corresponds to taking actions (steps), or sequences of actions (steps),
that either lead to a desired performance or improve the relative performance of individuals. This
process of looking for a desired performance or improved performances is called search.
Three main concepts are then involved in problem solving

    2. Specification of the objective: This is a mathematical statement of the task to be achieved like

    3. Definition of an evaluation function: it is the function that is used to evaluate the quality of the

Search problem can be of both maximization or minimization like min(f(x) = max -f(x).
The point that satisfies the objective function is called global solution. However, it is not possible to find
the global solution in all the cases so we find the best solution.
Search techniques does two things exploiting the best solutions found so far and at the same time
exploring the search space.</p>
<p>The figure describes the global minima that is actual the correct solution. However, while exploring for
the best solution, we may end up with minimum solution generally termed as local minima.
Hill Climbing
Hill climbing is a local search method that uses an iterative improvement strategy.
At each iteration, a new point x&#039; is selected by performing a small displacement or perturbation in the
current point x
x&#039; = x + ∆x

Any evolutionary system presents a number of features:
    1. Population(s): in all evolutionary systems there are populations, or groups, of entities, generally
       termed individuals.
    2. Reproduction: in order for evolution to occur, the individuals of the population(s) must
       reproduce either sexually or asexually.
    3. Variation: there is variation in one or more characteristics of the individuals of the population(s).
    4. Hereditary similarity: parent and offspring individuals present similar characteristics. Over the
       course of generations, there may be changes in the proportions of individuals with different
       characteristics within a population; a process called descent with modification.
    5. Sorting of variations: among the sorting processes, it can be emphasized chance (random
       variation in the survival or reproduction of different variants), and natural selection (consistent,
       non-random differences among variants in their rates of survival and reproduction).
Darwin describes some basic rules that promote improvements in organisms: reproduce, change and
compete for survival.
Natural selection was the term used by Darwin to explain how new characters arising from variations
are preserved.
In summary, according to Darwin’s theory, evolution is a result of a population of individuals that suffer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Reproduction with inheritance. • Variation. • Natural selection.
Standard Evolutionary Algorithm A standard evolutionary algorithm can be proposed as follows:</li>

<li>A population of individuals that reproduce with inheritance. Each individual represents or encodes a
point in a search space of potential solutions to a problem. These individuals are allowed to reproduce
(sexually or asexually), generating offspring that inherit some features (traits) from their parents. These
inherited traits cause the offspring to present resemblance with their progenitors.<ul>
<li>Genetic variation. Offspring are prone to genetic variation through mutation, which alters their
genetic makeup. Mutation allows the appearance of new traits in the offspring and, thus, the
exploration of new regions of the search space.</li>

<li>Natural selection. The evaluation of individuals in their environment results in a measure of
adaptability, quality, or fitness value to be assigned to them. A comparison of individual finesses will
lead to a competition for survival and reproduction in the environment, and there will be a selective
advantage for those individuals of higher fitness.</li>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
<p>Crossover
Two strings x = x 1 x 2 ... xl and y = y 1 y2 ... yl are selected from the current population P.
A number r indicating the crossover point is randomly selected from {1, 2, ... , l−1}.
Two new strings are formed from x and y by exchanging the set of attributes to the right of position r,
yielding x’ = x1 ... xi yi+1... yl and y’ = y1 ... yi xi+1 ... xl.
Mutation
mutation is a process wherein one allele of a gene is randomly replaced by (or modified to) another to
yield a new chromosome (structure).
The numbers r,...,u indicating the positions to undergo mutation are determined by a random process
where each position has a small probability pm of undergoing mutation, independently of the other
positions.
A new string x’ = x1...xr...xu.. is generated where xr.. are drawn at random from the set of alleles for
each gene. In the case of bitstrings, if a position has an allele ‘0’, then it becomes ‘1’, else if it is originally
‘1’, then it becomes ‘0’
In the standard GA, selection - select - is performed via Roulette Wheel, reproduction - reproduce - is
performed by crossing-over pairs of the selected individuals, and genetic variation - variate - is
performed via mutation. Fitness evaluation - eval - depends on the problem under study
GA has the following main features: • Binary representation of the data structures. • Fixed population
size. • Single-point crossover. • Point mutation. • Roulette Wheel selection.
